ygData.msgSnippet: Tucson had no time to be alarmed.  He is quick to kneel down to Vestige, and picks him up gently.  He was not about to leave him behind. They re comming,

Tucson had no time to be alarmed.  He is quick to kneel down to Vestige, an=
d picks him up gently.  He was not about to leave him behind.

"They're com=
ming, Vestige, hold on, we may not be able to escape the horde, but we can =
lose them long enough to get our bearings."

Tucson takes his chances and p=
repares to get off the rail car, hoping to at least get Vestige to a safe p=
lace, even if it were just for a few moments, to assemble a reasonable stra=
tegy to get rid of the horde, perhaps even vanquish them.

"There has to be=
 some way to stop them.  Everything has a weakness, it's just a matter of f=
inding it.  No radar, no sonar, looks like my eyes will have to do."

--- I=

e does what any Autobot would do to try and defend himself.. Reach for a we=
apon he was well adept at using. But it was not there. He had forgotten tha=
t Straight Shot is his weapon when she transforms into his cross bow. He qu=
ickly remembers, and looks down at Vestige.
> >
> > " Rest in peace old fri=
end. It's all right, eventually I'll get my bearings."
> >
> > He bravely p=
repares to defend himself via un armed combat skills.
> >
> > " And somethi=
ng tells me I'll be learning very fast."
> 
> As Tuscon leaped to his feet =
he can see that the light of the day was
> beginning to pass and night was =
setting in. In the distance he could
> see what appeared to be shadowy shap=
es in the air. They looked
> different from the first set of insects that h=
e had seen. These were
> winged, and it was their wings in flight that he h=
eard as they
> approached. Also their bodies were longer, more like hornets=
, although
> they had six cleaver like claws that looked sharp enough to sl=
ice
> through anything.
> 
> There were three of them moving through the ai=
r, in the dimming light
> Tuscon could just see that their wings were a blu=
e white, their bodies
> were a darker blue. Their color scheme was startlin=
g close to
> Scourge's colors, or perhaps one of his sweeps. Also Tuscon's =
radar
> seemed to be unable to pick up these creatures. He could see them j=
ust
> fine, but his radar on which he was so used to depending was unable t=
o
> get a reading on them, and the insects were quickly approaching the
> c=
ar, the buzzing of their wings becoming louder and louder.
> 
> He could he=
ar that same feminine voice, "We are the horde, and we are
> coming for you=
. You cannot escape, because there is no where to go."
> 
> Meanwhile the c=
ar itself was puling in towards some sort of depot,
> although with the gro=
wing shadows of the day it was difficult to see
> inside far enough to see =
whether there was any sort of welcoming party
> there or not.
> 
> Nearby V=
estige moaned and stirred slightly. It would seem that he was
> not dead bu=
t had simply fell unconscious, the power requirements for
> the remainder o=
f his healing drawing off too much at once and shutting
> down his systems.=
